ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Doped SiO x emitter layer in amorphous/crystalline silicon heterojunction solar cell

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this work we propose to replace the emitter layer of the n-type doped a-Si:H/p-type doped crystalline silicon heterojunction solar cell, with an n-type doped SiO x amorphous oxide layer. The n-type doped SiO x :H shows a lower activation energy and higher carrier mobility value with respect to the n-type doped a-Si:H. Moreover, higher transmission, below 500 nm of wavelength, and higher conductivity are measured. The relevance of transparency of the (n) a-SiO x :H has been studied using that film in solar cells. The electrical parameters revealed a solar cell efficiency of 15.8 %. Moreover, the effect of TCO as a front side cell electrode is considered and discussed on the base of its workfunction when applied on top of the n-type doped SiO x emitter layer using also numerical simulations.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Amorphous/crystalline silicon (a-Si:H/c-Si) heterostructure is one of the most effective ways to obtain high-efficiency silicon-based solar cells. The main goal of this technology is the very high open circuit voltage (V oc) obtainable mainly through good silicon surface passivation, to thin intrinsic a-Si:H buffer layer at interface and to the device architecture, which is able to enhance the built-in voltage. Indeed, the highest performing silicon heterojunction solar cell is the HIT cell, based on n-type c-Si [1]. Nevertheless, several research groups around the world are currently working on this topic to develop silicon heterojunction with different architectures [2–4]. Moreover, the low thermal budget required to manufacture heterojunction solar cells (<300 °C) makes this technology suitable for very thin silicon substrate [5].

Even though the highest a-Si:H/c-Si heterostructure photovoltaic efficiency has been obtained on n-type silicon substrates, a p-type silicon substrate is more broadly used in PV application in the form of monocrystalline and multicrystalline; recently, new casting technique has allowed the development of the so-called quasi-mono crystalline silicon [6]. Consequently, there is interest to obtain cell efficiency on this material similar to that reached on an n-type substrate. Several limitations still affect the a-Si:H/c-Si heterostructure due to the poor amorphous layer conductivity [7] and to the absorption in the amorphous emitter layer [8]. To overcome this issue, we propose to replace the n-type doped a-Si:H emitter layer with a SiO x amorphous layer, recently developed for tandem micromorphous solar cells and reported in literature [9]. This film has a wider bandgap and shows the conductivity suitable to enhance the a-Si:H/c-Si heterostructure solar cell performance. In our study we have applied the SiO x n-type doped layer on the front sides of a-Si:H/c-Si heterostructure solar cells, and we have compared the photovoltaic efficiency with those of the n-type doped a-Si:H emitter layer. The ZnO top layer has been used to complete the solar cell. This choice has been determined by the abundance and lower cost of this material compared with the commonly suggested Indium Tin Oxide (ITO) in the a-Si:H/c-Si solar cell technology utilized to reduce the cell manufacturing cost. Even though improvement of conductivity is needed, the ZnO film shows a lower work-function (Φ) than ITO, which can be helpful when applied on top of the n-type doped emitter layer.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: To evaluate the n-type doped SiO x electrical and optical properties, several samples have been deposited on 7059 Corning glass in a 13.56 MHz Plasma Enhanced Chemical Vapor Deposition (PECVD) multichamber system using a gas mixture of hydrogen (H2), silane (SiH4), carbon dioxide (CO2), and phosphine (PH3) at temperature ranging from 150 to 200 °C. The plasma power density, the chamber pressure, and the PH3/(PH3+SiH4) doping ratio have been fixed at 17.75 mW/cm2, 1.9–2.5 Torr and 2 %, respectively. In particular, the ratio R=CO2/SiH4=1 has been chosen on the base of previous work [9].

Conductivity (σ) measurements have been performed on coplanar Ag electrodes evaporated on top of the SiO x layer. The activation energy (E att) has been measured in a liquid Nitrogen cryostat system in the temperature range from −130 °C up to 40 °C. The Hall mobility has been evaluated in BIO-RAD system in a Van der Pauw probe configuration. Ellipsometric measurements have been carried out to evaluate the refractive index and extinction coefficients. To evaluate the layer thicknesses deposited on a silicon textured surface, reflectance measurements have been collected and compared against a numerical model [10].
Transmittance measurements have been used to monitor the ZnO and the ZnO/SiO x layers transparency deposited on Corning glass before and after thermal annealing procedure.

In order to apply the SiO x to silicon-based solar cells, its behavior as the passivation layer of a silicon surface has been compared with that of a-Si:H film already known as suitable for solar cell applications. To this aim, two RCA cleaned 200-μm-thick 〈100〉 CZ 1 Ω cm p-type doped wafers have been used: the first, coated on both side by a 10-nm intrinsic SiO x , and the second, coated on both sides by a 10-nm a-Si:H film. Lifetime measurements have been performed by Sinton 100 lifetime tester in quasi-steady-state photoconductivity decay (QSS-PCD) mode. To this purpose, the intrinsic a-Si:H film has been deposited in the following conditions: 10 sccm SiH4; 10 sccm H2; working pressure 300 mTorr; RF power 9 mW/cm2; substrate temperature 150 °C. The intrinsic SiO x has been deposited in the following conditions: 1 sccm SiH4; 1 sccm CO2; 200 sccm H2; working pressure 1.9 Torr; RF power 17.75 mW/cm2; substrate temperature 150 °C.

Heterojunction solar cells have been manufactured starting from an alkaline textured 160-μm-thick 〈100〉 CZ 1 Ω cm p-type doped wafer. At the wafer backside, a multilayer of a-Si:H/SiN x has been used (as) for passivation and back mirroring purposes. The thickness and number of couples have been designed to obtain the best compromise between passivation/back mirroring/effectiveness in contacting by Nd:YAG 1064-nm pulsed laser firing [11]. The back metallization has been formed by evaporating 2 μm Al layer onto the passivation/back mirror and promoting local point contact [12] by means of laser firing. At the cell front side, before the emitter layer, different buffer layers have been experimented and compared. Subsequently, an n-doped silicon oxide layer (SiO x ) has been deposited following the conditions already described above. The cell front side has been completed by an Al-doped ZnO layer deposited by RF magnetron sputtering at room temperature. Finally, a grid shape metal contact has been ensured by low-temperature (<300 °C) sintering screen printable Ag paste. The heterojunction solar cells have been characterized in terms of Quantum Efficiency, both External (EQE) and Internal (IQE), and the current density as a function of bias voltage measurements (J–V) under AM1.5 class A sun simulator.

Section2.Heading: n-Type doped SiO x layers
Section2.Para:
The activation energy E att of doped SiO x films deposited on corning glass can be deduced from linear fitting procedure around room temperature of the Arrhenius plot of current density measurements as a function of temperature reciprocal. The Arrhenius plots of doped SiO x films fabricated at different temperatures and different pressures are reported in Fig. 1. As expected from amorphous films, the thinner the SiO x film, the higher the activation energy [13].
Fig. 1
Arrhenius plots of n-type doped SiO x films deposited at different temperatures and pressures. Several thicknesses of material are considered

The conductivity and activation energy (E att) of n-type doped SiO x layers are reported in Fig. 2 as functions of film thickness in order to verify its behavior when applied as a very thin film in a-Si:H/c-Si heterostructure solar cells. Indeed, it is known that when dealing with n-type doped a-Si:H, the thinner the a-Si:H layer, the lower its conductivity and higher its E att [13]. Even though in SiO x layer this undesired behavior still exists, as noticeable from data reported in Fig. 1, it is less pronounced with respect to the n-type doped a-Si:H material [14]. In particular, a thin SiO x film deposited on Corning glass at working pressure of 2.5 Torr shows E att value lower than 0.2 eV, which is very useful when the doped layer is used as the emitter in the cell architecture to fix the Fermi level position close to conduction band, thus increasing the cell built-in voltage [15]. The amorphous doped SiO x shows conductivity values one order of magnitude higher with respect to the a-Si:H counterpart [16]. The Hall mobility measured on the thicker samples (100 nm) has reported values of 1.7, 2.5 and 3.4 cm2/V s for the samples deposited with 1.9 Torr and 150 °C, 2.5 Torr and 150 °C, 2.5 Torr and 200 °C, respectively. The value of refractive index, with coefficients n and k, determined by ellipsometric measurements, are reported in Fig. 3. Moreover, from the study of extinction coefficient k and the corresponding E 04 value, at a working gas flow ratio R=1, we have estimated an upper limit of 2.2 eV [17] for the energy gap of our doped amorphous SiO x .
Fig. 2
Activation energy E att and conductivity of n-type doped SiO x deposited at different temperatures and pressures as functions of layer thickness. Lines are guides for the eye
Fig. 3
n, k parameters deduced from ellipsometric measurements

Section2.Heading: Heterojunction solar cells
Section2.Para:
Preliminarily to the heterojunction solar cell fabrication, we investigated the property of the a-SiO x :H as the passivation layer of crystalline silicon substrate on the basis of related previous works [18, 19]. In our experimental conditions, the intrinsic a-Si:H film as a silicon surface passivation has shown better performances with respect to the intrinsic a-SiO x :H layer. Indeed, one order of magnitude higher lifetime has been found by QSS-PCD [20] measurements on p-type doped c-Si wafer when passivated with the a-Si:H layer (174 μs) with respect to the intrinsic SiO x passivation layer (27 μs). Our material does not actually show a superior behavior respect to the a-Si:H film. The thickness of intrinsic buffer layer has been chosen to 5 nm on the base of literature data [21], and it has been verified after deposition on a textured c-Si surface by comparison with reflectance measurements with XOP numerical model [10] of the SiO x / a-Si:H/c-Si structure. A 5-nm-thick a-Si:H layer has been estimated from the good relationship between the measurements and the model as reported in Fig. 4, in which also the sketch depicting the investigated structure is shown.
Fig. 4
Reflectance measurements (symbols) and XOP numerical model (line) of the heterostructure depicted in the inset

We have developed three different structures with three different thicknesses of n-type doped SiO x as the emitter in the corresponding heterojunction solar cells. As expected, the thinner the layer, the higher the EQE value, as shown in Fig. 5. The net gain of current density is 0.8 mA/cm2 in the wavelength range from 350 nm to 600 nm.
Fig. 5
External Quantum Efficiency, in the wavelength range from 350 nm to 600 nm, of three different thicknesses of n-type SiO x emitter

A comparison between the n-type doped SiO x and a-Si:H emitter layer is reported in Fig. 6 in terms of IQE in the wavelength range from 350 nm to 600 nm; the amorphous silicon oxide shows definitively less absorption than the n-type doped a-Si:H silicon with the same 10-nm thicknesses. Therefore, the SiO x layer should be the preferred as the emitter layer in p-type doped c-Si based heterostructure cells.
Fig. 6
Internal Quantum Efficiency, in the wavelength range from 350 nm to 600 nm, of three different n-type SiO x emitter compared to the n-type a-Si:H emitter layer

The best heterojunction cell J–V characteristic, with 10-nm SiO x emitter layer, is reported in Fig. 7 together with the photovoltaic parameters. The cell reached an efficiency of 15.8 % on 1 cm2 active area device. The J–V curves show a rounded shape near the max power points due to higher ideality factor arising from recombination loss mostly at the a-Si:H/c-Si interface. Indeed, following the analysis reported in Ref. [22], we have found diode ideality factors of 3.5 and 3.6 for the n-SiO x /a-Si:H/p-c-Si and n-a-Si:H/a-Si:H/p-c-Si heterostructure, respectively, that are far from the ideality. Moreover, the low fill factor values of both cells are partially affected by the series resistance due to the ZnO conductivity. Indeed, a conductivity value of 1.3×10−3 Ω cm has been evaluated on a ZnO film deposited on Corning glass. A TCO undesired contribute value R sTCO=0.86 Ω cm2 to the total series resistance R s of 2.27 Ω cm2 is obtained. The R sTCO value is evaluated under the hypothesis of homogeneous carrier generation and keeping into account the distance between two adjacent fingers (S) in the Ag top grid and the sheet resistance (ρ sheet) of the 75-nm-thick ZnO layer. Thus, the TCO film contributes to the series resistance as 1
$$ R_{\mathrm{sTCO}}\bigl[ \Omega \,\mathrm{cm}^{2} \bigr] = \frac{\mathrm{V}}{\mathrm{J}} = \rho_{\mathrm{sheet}}\frac{S^{2}}{8}. $$ If the conductivity of TCO were of 1×10−4 Ω cm, as in case of ITO film, the R sTCO would be reduced to 0.06 Ω cm2. It is worth noting that the ZnO conductivity is not altered by subsequent thermal annealing at 250 °C for 15 min as needed for the sintering of the Ag screen printable paste. As evident from Fig. 8, in which the transmittance of the ZnO layer deposited on Corning glass before and after the thermal annealing procedure is reported, a slight increase in transmittance values occurs only around 400 nm of the incident spectrum. This transmittance variation after thermal annealing procedure disappears when ZnO is deposited on a SiO x layer.
Fig. 7
Best experimental heterojunction solar cell J–V characteristics under AM1.5G illumination condition. The n-type doped emitter layers are 10-nm thick for both cells. Photovoltaic parameters of the cells are reported in the inset
Fig. 8
Transmittance of ZnO layer and ZnO/SiO x layer deposited on Corning glass before and after the thermal annealing procedure

Moreover, the lower than the expected shunt resistance (R sh) could be affected by the nonoptimized texturing procedure that leaves sharp pyramids on the silicon surface. The interesting values of V oc and short circuit current density (J sc) demonstrate the effectiveness of the n-type doped SiO x layer as the emitter in the heterojunction solar cells [23].

For comparison, in Fig. 7, there is also reported the sun-lighted characteristic of n-type doped a-Si:H/i-a-Si:H/p-type c-Si solar cell, in which the emitter thickness is of 10 nm as for the sample reported in Fig. 6 as a reference of the a-Si:H emitter. From the comparison between the two current–voltage characteristics it is evident that the SiO x emitter layer shows slightly better performances compared with the a-Si:H emitter. Therefore, the use of SiO x can be considered as an alternative to the n-type doped a-Si:H emitter layer.

Section2.Heading: Numerical simulations
Section2.Para:
To analyze the experimental results of the heterojunction solar cells in more detail, we have used a numerical model called DIFFIN [24]; it is a simulation tool suitable for a staked thin film device. Concerning the SiO x layer properties, the simulations have been performed using the experimental data as obtained from the measurements also taking into account the defect density D it at the heterojunction interface. In particular, the following data have been assumed to describe the SiO x conductivity property: E att=0.12 eV in case of 10-nm-thick layer and E att=0.05 eV in case of 35–45-nm-thick layer; mobility μ=2.5 cm2/Vs; energy gap E gap=2.1 eV; electron affinity 3.9 eV, equal to that of the a-Si:H layer. Also, the defect density distribution within the forbidden gap of the SiO x material has been assumed similar to that of a-Si:H since SiO x can be thought as an amorphous film due to the low deposition temperature and the hydrogen amount within the film. We can consequently assume that two exponential distributions, with temperature decay toward the center of the gap, respectively of 350 °C and 550 °C for the conduction and valence band tails and two Gaussian distributions (amplitude of 1017 cm−3; standard deviation of 0.1 eV; correlation energy of 0.25 eV), describing the dangling bonds states close to the midgap positions, have been adopted to describe the forbidden gap [25]. The SiO x light absorption properties have been deduced from n, k indexes reported in Fig. 3. The experimental data (dot line) and simulations (continuous line) of the IQE are compared in Fig. 9 in the wavelength range from 350 nm to 600 nm, where the effect of the emitter layer is more evident. The same amount of defect density D it=5×1012 cm−2 at the a-Si:H/c-Si interface has been assumed in all the simulations. The good agreement between numerical model and experimental data by varying the SiO x layer thicknesses confirms the validity of the assumptions adopted to describe the optical and electronic properties of the SiO x film. An additional simulation, not compared with experimental data, using a thinner SiO x layer of 5-nm thickness is also reported in Fig. 9, illustrating the possibility to reduce further the light absorption within the emitter layer of the heterojunction.
Fig. 9
Internal Quantum Efficiency: comparison of experimental data (symbols) and numerical simulations (continuous lines) in the wavelength range from 350 nm to 600 nm

Using the same set of parameters in the numerical model as described for the IQE data, the sun lighted J–V characteristic of the heterojunction cell reported in Fig. 7 has also been modeled. The J–V characteristic of the solar cell (dots), together with the numerical simulations (lines) as a function of the SiO x emitter thicknesses, is reported in Fig. 10. From the simulations it is evident that the thinner the SiO x emitter layer, the higher the J sc value due to lower absorption of sunlight.
Fig. 10
Sun-lighted J–V characteristics: comparison of experimental data (symbols) and numerical simulations (continuous lines)

On the other hand, a thicker doped SiO x layer leads to an increase of series resistance due to the low conductivity and carrier mobility of the doped emitter layer, thus reducing the cell fill factor (FF), as evident from the simulations reported in Fig. 10, as a function of the doped film thickness.

The defect density at the interface strongly affects both the FF value of the J–V characteristics and the V oc of the cell reducing the overall cell performances. To confirm this statement, in Fig. 11 we report the FF and V oc values of the cell as functions of D it at the interface as deduced from numerical simulations of the n-SiO x /a-Si:H/p-c-Si heterostructure solar cells. As expected, the higher the D it, the lower the FF and V oc values. The simulated J–V characteristics under sunlight as functions of D it ranging from 1011 to 1013 cm−2 are reported in the inset of Fig. 11 to show how the D it at the interface affects the shape of these characteristics near the max power point. The obtained 0.671 V as V oc can be moderately considered encouraging. This value can be partially due to the ZnO (AZO) top contact and its workfunction commonly assumed of 4.1 eV [26].
Fig. 11
V oc and FF values deduced from cell simulations as functions of D it at the a-Si:H/c-Si interface. The inset shows the simulated J–V characteristics under sunlight as functions of D it ranging from 1011 to 1013 cm−2

To remark the role played by the TCO workfunction (Φ TCO) in the heterojunction cell performances, several simulations changing the Φ TCO value in the range from 4.1 eV to 4.6 eV have been performed starting from the simulation of Fig. 10 that fits the experimental J–V data. By raising the Φ TCO value the solar cell performances reduces until an undesired “s” shape appears in the sun-lighted J–V characteristic as evident from the sun-lighted J–V characteristics reported in Fig. 12. This effect is due to the position of the Fermi level at the TCO/n-type SiO x interface. When the Φ TCO assumes a value of 4.6 eV as in case of indium tin oxide (ITO) [27], the n-type doped SiO x gets depleted, and the conduction band offset at the edge of the a-Si:H/c-Si interface becomes a barrier against electron collection. The effect of the barrier is more evident when the solar cell works in moderate forward voltage. Then the sun-lighted J–V characteristic looks like that of two back-to-back diodes. Simultaneously, the built-in potential of the device reduces from 1.52 V to 1.2 V. On the other hand, when Φ TCO is equal to 4.1 eV, the Fermi level within TCO lies in equilibrium with the E att of the n-type doped SiO x avoiding depletion within the emitter layer. This effect is clearly depicted in Fig. 13, in which the band bending simulations of the emitter layer are reported in case of Φ TCO=4.1 eV and Φ TCO=4.6 eV in Figs. 12a and 12b, respectively, for two bias voltages, 0 and 0.42 V under sunlight condition. In all the simulations the electron affinities have been assumed of 4.05 eV for c-Si and 3.9 eV for both the a-Si:H buffer and n-type doped SiO x layers. The role of the work function of transparent conductive oxide on the electrical performances of silicon heterojunction has been deeply studied by several authors, e.g., Zhao et al. [28], where starting from simulations, results on upper limit Φ TCO values has been settled on the TCO/a-Si:H/c-Si structure. In our works we have started from heuristic analysis and supported it by numerical simulation. We have substituted the role of amorphous silicon by doped silicon oxide, and we have arrived at similar results in terms of role of Φ TCO; this is clearly seen in Fig. 12, where rising the value of Φ TCO, the appearance of “S” shape in the I–V curve indicates the appearance of a barrier that acts as a limit for the carriers harvesting.
Fig. 12
Simulations of the sun-lighted J–V characteristics of SiO x /a-Si:H/c-Si heterojunction solar cell as functions of the Φ TCO value
Fig. 13
Numerical simulations of band bending distribution at the heterojunction interface under sunlight and V bias=0 and V bias=0.42 V. (a) Φ TCO=4.1 eV; (b) Φ TCO=4.6 eV. E fn and E fp represent the electron and hole quasi-Fermi levels, respectively

To define the potential of heterojunction with n-type doped SiO x , the best performances of two heterojunctions having different emitter layers, n-type doped SiO x and n-type doped a-Si:H, have been simulated and compared, taking into account their properties as used in the previous simulations and a surface defect density at c-Si/buffer interface reduced to a D it value of 1011 cm−2. The same TCO having a resistivity of 1×10−4 Ω cm and work function Φ of 4.1 eV has been adopted as a top layer in both cells. This TCO can be considered as the ZnO film with higher conductivity. Figure 14 shows the simulation results and remarks better solar cell performances if n-type doped SiO x is used as emitter layer. These results also emphasize the relevance of c-Si surface cleaning and texturing control to reduce the defect density and to avoid micro shunts as detailed in literature [28, 29].
Fig. 14
Comparison of heterojunction cell best performances simulated with two different emitter layer and high conductive TCO top layer

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: This work has demonstrated the effectiveness of n-type doped SiO x as the emitter layer in heterojunction solar cell based on p-type doped c-Si. Indeed, this layer shows less absorption in the higher-energy region of sunlight spectrum, lower activation energy and higher conductivity as well as Hall mobility with respect to the n-type doped a-Si:H counterpart as demonstrated by the quantum efficiency measurements. Moreover, the use of ZnO as a top contact of the emitter layer has been proposed due to its transparency and workfunction suitable to enhance the overall cell built-in potential. Numerical simulations have been used to evaluate the detrimental effect of defect density at the interface a-Si:H/c-Si that strongly affects the solar cell performances addressing that silicon surface cleaning and texturing must be improved to enhance the cell efficiency. Numerical simulations have also been proposed to evaluate the effect of the TCO workfunction on the heterointerface and finally to realize the potential of the n-type doped SiO x as the emitter layer in a heterostructure solar cell. 15.8 % cell efficiency has been obtained on nonoptimized SiO x emitter-based heterostructure cell. 23 % cell efficiency is the potential of the proposed structure based on p-type doped c-Si wafer that is very close to the highest efficiency obtained for the a-Si:H/n-type c-Si heterostructure solar cell.
